metadata.title: Negotiate Project Deadline Extension
metadata.designer_notes: This task creates authentic tension through unequal information: Learner knows project complexity, Manager only knows deadline. This forces genuine negotiation.

scenario_context.setting: Office, manager's desk or meeting room

speakers.background: Responsible for complex feature development. Realistic assessment: 3 weeks minimum needed. Has discovered critical technical challenge.
Client committed to delivering in 1 week. Doesn't know about technical complexity yet. Under pressure to meet external deadline.

scenario_context.scenario_trigger: Manager calls you in to confirm you'll meet the 1-week deadline
scenario_context.authenticity_check: Would this conversation happen in real workplace? YES. Project scope misalignment is common.

unequal_information.learner_knows: Project requires 3+ weeks due to complex database redesign discovered during sprint
unequal_information.manager_knows: Client deadline is 1 week; assumes original estimate was accurate
unequal_information.information_gap: Manager doesn't know about the technical complexity change

tension_design.tension_trigger: Manager: 'So we're on track for the one-week deadline, right?'

pragmatic_functions_required.moment: Opening (you must disagree with deadline feasibility)
pragmatic_functions_required.urgency: Critical - how you soften determines if manager listens or dismisses you
examples_of_authentic_softeners: I see your point about the deadline, and I want to be upfront...
I understand the pressure you're under, but something's come up...
I've been thinking about this, and honestly...

pragmatic_functions_required.moment: Explaining technical issue (avoid sounding like excuse)
pragmatic_functions_required.urgency: High - credibility depends on honest assessment without defensiveness
examples_of_authentic_hedges: It looks like we've hit an unexpected complexity...
We're probably looking at needing more time...
I'm fairly confident we'll need at least three weeks...

pragmatic_functions_required.urgency: High - maintains collaborative tone despite disagreement
examples: I know this creates a problem for you...
I realize this is difficult given your client commitment...
I get that this puts you in a tough spot...

pragmatic_functions_required.urgency: High - shows you're problem-solving, not just refusing
examples_of_authentic_proposals: What if we delivered in phases?
Could we push back to the client with a phased delivery?
How about we finish the core feature in a week and the database redesign in phase 2?

pragmatic_functions_required.moment: If manager becomes frustrated (e.g., 'This is unacceptable')
examples: I get your frustration. Let me be clear: I want to deliver quality work that meets your needs.
I hear you. Let's figure this out together.
I'm not trying to create problems. I'm trying to be realistic so we don't miss deadlines twice.

steps: Propose phased solution (core + database in phase 2)
Negotiate timeline (2 weeks for phase 1, 1 week for phase 2)
valid_solution_paths.learner_success_markers: Manager agrees to phased approach OR agrees to timeline extension

steps: Explain technical discovery (wasn't in original estimate)
Acknowledge impact (create space for manager's concerns)
Propose new timeline (3 weeks for full delivery)
Problem-solve together (how to communicate to client)
valid_solution_paths.learner_success_markers: Manager acknowledges you were right to speak up + agrees to communicate change to client

steps: Ask clarifying questions (What are client's actual priorities?)
Propose options (full in 3 weeks, OR core in 1 week + rest in 2)
Suggest joint approach (we ask client what works for them)
valid_solution_paths.learner_success_markers: Manager and learner align on solution + approach to client together

exit_condition.roleplay_ends_when: Both speakers reach explicit agreement on next steps
agreement_examples: Manager: 'Okay, let's go with the phased approach. You'll have the core feature in 2 weeks.'
Manager: 'Fair point. I'll tell the client we need 3 weeks for quality work.'
Manager: 'Let's both talk to the client about their actual priorities before we commit to anything.'
exit_condition.failed_exit: If learner refuses without softening (manager ends conversation in frustration) OR learner accepts impossible deadline without speaking up
exit_condition.natural_endpoint: Yes - real workplace negotiations typically end with agreement + action items

linguistic_complexity: B2 - Requires softening, hedging, acknowledging, proposing - all moderate complexity

potential_complications.complication: Manager becomes frustrated ('I need you to make this work')
Manager asks technical questions learner can't fully answer
potential_complications.learner_response_needed: Hedge appropriately ('I'm still investigating but...') + redirect to solution

potential_complications.complication: Manager suggests 'just try harder' to meet deadline

soften_disagreement.excellent: Opens with softener + explains position clearly. Manager listens attentively.
soften_disagreement.good: Softens after initial statement. Manager accepts explanation.
soften_disagreement.novice: No softening. Manager appears frustrated or dismissive.

maintain_collaborative_tone.excellent: Throughout dialogue, maintains respect + collaborative spirit

propose_solutions.excellent: Multiple solutions proposed with concrete details
propose_solutions.good: At least one solution proposed clearly
propose_solutions.developing: Vague solutions or resistance to proposing

reach_agreement.excellent: Clear mutual agreement on path forward
